The metric chosen to predict the mechanical properties, thermal exposure time, and temperature of the epoxy resin is Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR)-spectroscopy. This technique measures molecular changes in the resin samples using mid-IR (MIR)-FTIR for film samples and near-IR (NIR)-FTIR for bulk samples. 

The FTIR spectra in the MIR-range were analyzed quantitatively for film samples, revealing oxidation, chain-scission, and dehydration. For bulk samples, only minor changes in the FTIR spectra could be detected using NIR spectroscopy.

Output: Yes, the approach of using FTIR-spectroscopy, data processing, and artificial neural networks can be considered superior to traditional methods in accurately predicting the mechanical properties, thermal exposure time, and temperature of epoxy resin. Traditional methods for detecting thermal degradation in epoxy resins and composites are limited to severe thermal damage and do not provide accurate predictions for short-time thermal exposure or the history of thermally degraded polymers.
